titles.title: Rising Oceans Guaranteed: Arctic Land Ice Loss and Sea Level Rise

custom_metadata.assertion: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.

assertion.group_label: Human and Animal Rights and Informed Consent
assertion.name: Ethics

custom_metadata.assertion: This article does not contain any studies with human or animal subjects performed by any of the authors.

citation.unstructured_citation: •• AMAP (2017) Snow, water, ice and permafrost in the Arctic (SWIPA) 2017. Arctic Monitoring and Assessment Programme (AMAP), XIV:269. Comprehensive overview of recent and expected changes of the Arctic hydro- and cryosphere.

citation.author: M Morlighem
citation.unstructured_citation: •• Morlighem M, Williams CN, Rignot E, et al. BedMachine v3: Complete bed topography and ocean bathymetry mapping of Greenland from multibeam echo sounding combined with mass conservation. Geophys Res Lett. 2017;44:11051–11. 061. The most recent bed topography for underneath the Greenland Ice Sheet, including near-ice fjord bathymetry that incorporates new interpolation methods.

Overland JE, Hanna E, Hanssen-Bauer I, Kim SJ, Walsh J, Wang M, Bhatt US, Thoman RL (2016) Surface air temperature [in Artic Report Card 2016], http://www.arctic.noaa.gov/Report-Card
.

•• IPCC, 2013. Climate change 2013: the physical science basis. Contribution of Working Group I to the Fifth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. In: Stocker TF, Qin D, Plattner G-K, Tignor M, Allen SK, Boschung J, Nauels A, Xia Y, Bex V, Midgley PM, editors. . Cambridge, UK and New York, NY, USA: Cambridge University Press. p. 1535. https://doi.org/10.1017/CBO9781107415324
. This synthesis report is a key reference for understanding the state of climate change science and projections for future change.

citation.author: X Chen
citation.unstructured_citation: • Chen X, Zhang X, Church JA, Watson CS, King MA, Monselesan D, et al. The increasing rate of global mean sea-level rise during 1993–2014. Nat Clim Chang. 2017;7:492–5. Observational advances in closing the sea-level rise budget and understanding role of ice, including Greenland, in total sea level rise. Excellent abstract and recommended figures 3 and 4.

citation.author: HB Dieng
citation.unstructured_citation: Dieng HB, Cazenave A, Meyssignac B, Ablain M. New estimate of the current rate of sea level rise from a sea level budget approach. Geophys Res Lett. 2017;44:3744–51.

citation.author: CC Hay
citation.unstructured_citation: • Hay CC, Morrow E, Kopp RE, Mitrovica JX. Probabilistic reanalysis of twentieth-century sea-level rise. Nature. 2015;517:481–4. Recommend figure 2 to see convergence of sea level rise estimates from 1900 to present (data/method improvements) and acceleration in sea-level rise since 1990s.

citation.author: M Ablain
citation.unstructured_citation: Ablain M, Legeais JF, Prandi P, Marcos M, Fenoglio-Marc L, Dieng HB, et al. Satellite altimetry-based sea level at global and regional scales. Surv Geophys. 2016;38:7–31.

citation.author: JL Bamber
citation.unstructured_citation: •• Bamber JL, Westaway RM, Marzeion B, Wouters B. The land ice contribution to sea level during the satellite era. Environ Res Lett. 2018;13:063008–22. A recent review of global sea level rise from land ice loss, including new data synthesis to provide globally consistent 5-year measurement periods during 1992-2016.

citation.author: A Shepherd
citation.unstructured_citation: Shepherd A, Ivins ER, Geruo A, et al. A reconciled estimate of ice-sheet mass balance. Science. 2012;338:1183–9.

citation.author: SA Khan
citation.unstructured_citation: •• Khan SA, Aschwanden A, Bjørk AA, Wahr J, Kjeldsen KK, Kjær KH. Greenland ice sheet mass balance: a review. Rep Prog Phys. 2015;78:1–26. A thorough and in-depth review with excellent figures. Recommend figures 11 and 14.

citation.author: ML Andersen
citation.unstructured_citation: • Andersen ML, Stenseng L, Skourup H, et al. Basin-scale partitioning of Greenland ice sheet mass balance components (2007–2011). Earth Planet Sc Lett. 2015;409:89–95. Useful regional Greenland ice sheet mass data for surface mass balance and discharge (summary in figure 4). Valuable ~1990-2013 ice loss synthesis shown in figure 3.

citation.author: E Rignot
citation.unstructured_citation: Rignot E, Velicogna I, Van Den Broeke MR, Monaghan A, Lenaerts J. Acceleration of the contribution of the Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets to sea level rise. Geophys Res Lett. 2011;38:L05503.
Enderlin EM, Howat IM, Jeong S, Noh MJ, Angelen JH, Broeke MR (2014) An improved mass budget for the Greenland ice sheet. Geophys Res Lett. https://doi.org/10.1002/(ISSN)1944-8007

citation.author: M Zemp
citation.unstructured_citation: • Zemp M, Frey H, Gärtner-Roer I, et al. Historically unprecedented global glacier decline in the early 21st century. J Glaciol. 2015;61:745–62. Shows that the rates of early 21st century mass loss are without historical precedence on a global scale.

citation.author: DB Bahr
citation.unstructured_citation: Bahr DB, Pfeffer WT, Kaser G. A review of volume-area scaling of glaciers. Rev Geophys. 2015;53:95–140.

citation.author: RA Bindschadler
citation.unstructured_citation: Bindschadler RA, Nowicki S, Abe-Ouchi A, et al. Ice-sheet model sensitivities to environmental forcing and their use in projecting future sea level (the SeaRISE project). J Glaciol. 2013;59:195–224.

citation.author: S Nowicki
citation.unstructured_citation: Nowicki S, Bindschadler RA, Abe-Ouchi A, et al. Insights into spatial sensitivities of ice mass response to environmental change from the SeaRISE ice sheet modeling project II: Greenland. J Geophys Res-Earth. 2013;118:1025–44.

citation.author: SMJ Nowicki
citation.unstructured_citation: • Nowicki SMJ, Payne A, Larour E, Seroussi H, Goelzer H, Lipscomb W, et al. Ice Sheet Model Intercomparison Project (ISMIP6) contribution to CMIP6. Geosci Model Dev. 2016;9:4521–45. Presents a framework that allows for the first time in CMIP history for ice sheet model simulations (hence sea level from ice sheets) to be officially part of the CMIP effort.

citation.journal_title: Proceedings of the National Academies of Science
citation.author: SR Shannon
citation.unstructured_citation: Shannon SR, Payne AJ. Enhanced basal lubrication and the contribution of the Greenland ice sheet to future sea-level rise. Proceedings of the National Academies of Science. 2013;110:14156–14,161.

citation.author: H Goelzer
citation.unstructured_citation:
• Goelzer H, Nowicki S, Edwards T, Beckley M, Abe-Ouchi A, Aschwanden A, et al. Design and results of the ice sheet model initialisation experiments initMIP-Greenland: an ISMIP6 intercomparison. The Cryosphere. 2018;12:1433–60. https://doi.org/10.5194/tc-12-1433-2018
. First results of the ISMIP6 intercomparison effort, with a focus on the impact of model initialization on ice sheet projections.

citation.author: M Vizcaíno
citation.unstructured_citation: • Vizcaíno M, Mikolajewicz U, Ziemen F, Rodehacke CB, Greve R, Broeke MR. Coupled simulations of Greenland Ice Sheet and climate change up to AD. 2300. Geophys Res Lett. 2015;42:3927–35. One of the first future climate change projection for Greenland with a fully coupled comprehensive climate-ice sheet model.

citation.author: WH Lipscomb
citation.unstructured_citation: Lipscomb WH, Fyke JG, Vizcaíno M, Sacks WJ, Wolfe J, Vertenstein M, et al. Implementation and initial evaluation of the Glimmer Community Ice Sheet Model in the Community Earth System Model. J Climate. 2013;26:7352–71.

citation.author: SF Price
citation.unstructured_citation: • Price SF, Hoffman MJ, Bonin JA, et al. An ice sheet model validation framework for the Greenland ice sheet. Geosci Model Dev. 2017;10:255–70. Presents a web-based framework to facilitate the comparison between model simulations and observations.

citation.author: M Huss
citation.unstructured_citation: Huss M, Hock R. A new model for global glacier change and sea-level rise. Front Earth Sci. 2015;3:382–22.

citation.author: B Noël
citation.unstructured_citation: • Noël B, van de Berg WJ, Lhermitte S, Wouters B, Machguth H, Howat I, et al. A tipping point in refreezing accelerates mass loss of Greenland’s glaciers and ice caps. Nat Comms. 2017;8:14730. Identifies an important mechanism influencing ice loss for the present and future behavior of Arctic glaciers and ice caps.

citation.author: M Stibal
citation.unstructured_citation: Stibal M, Box JE, Cameron KA, et al. Algae drive enhanced darkening of bare ice on the Greenland ice sheet. Geophys Res Lett. 2017;44:11,463–71.

citation.author: S Lutz
citation.unstructured_citation: Lutz S, Anesio AM, Raiswell R, Edwards A, Newton RJ, Gill F, et al. The biogeography of red snow microbiomes and their role in melting arctic glaciers. Nat Comms. 2016;7:11968.

• Bondzio JH, Morlighem M, Seroussi H, Kleiner T, Rückamp M, Mouginot J, Moon T, Larour EY, Humbert A (2017) The mechanisms behind Jakobshavn Isbrae’s acceleration and mass loss: a 3D thermomechanical model study. Geophys Res Lett. https://doi.org/10.1002/2017GL073309
. A modeling study that shows that calving front position is the dominant control for changes in the Jakobshavn Isbrae glacier over the last two decades.

citation.author: DI Benn
citation.unstructured_citation: Benn DI, Cowton T, Todd J, Luckman A. Glacier calving in Greenland. Current Climate Change Reports. 2017;3:282.

citation.author: D Felikson
citation.unstructured_citation: • Felikson D, Bartholomaus TC, Catania GA, et al. Inland thinning on the Greenland ice sheet controlled by outlet glacier geometry. Nat Geosci. 2017;116:101–6. A novel approach to identify which glaciers are vulnerable to future thinning using a threshold that accounts for glacier geometry.

citation.author: EM Enderlin
citation.unstructured_citation: Enderlin EM, Howat IM, Vieli A. High sensitivity of tidewater outlet glacier dynamics to shape. The Cryosphere. 2013;7:1007–15.

citation.author: M Morlighem
citation.unstructured_citation: Morlighem M, Bondzio J, Seroussi H. Modeling of Store Gletscher’s calving dynamics, West Greenland, in response to ocean thermal forcing. Geophys Res Lett. 2016;43:2659–66.

citation.author: Y Choi
citation.unstructured_citation: • Choi Y, Morlighem M, Rignot E, Mouginot J, Wood M. Modeling the response of Nioghalvfjerdsfjorden and Zachariae Isstrøm Glaciers, Greenland, to ocean forcing over the Next Century. Geophys Res Lett. 2017;44(11):071–11. 079. A study that demonstrates that marine ice sheet instability may be currently occurring on some Greenland glaciers. The retreat of the ice front would only be stopped once the ice front reaches topographical pinning points.

citation.author: T Moon
citation.unstructured_citation: • Moon T, Joughin I, Smith B, Broeke MR, Berg WJ, Noël B, et al. Distinct patterns of seasonal Greenland glacier velocity. Geophys Res Lett. 2014;41:7209–16. Establishes a useful classification scheme for seasonally varying Greenland ice sheet outlet glaciers, linking different classes to their plausible physical cause.

citation.author: M Tedesco
citation.unstructured_citation: •• Tedesco M, Doherty S, Fettweis X, Alexander P, Jeyaratnam J, Stroeve J. The darkening of the Greenland ice sheet: trends, drivers, and projections (1981–2100). The Cryosphere. 2016;10:477–96. Indicates that the recent decline in albedo over the Greenland ice sheet is primarily driven by melt-induced surface changes due to a warming climate. Also points out that the darkening process is currently inadequately modelled, resulting in an underestimated future contribution to sea level change.

citation.author: M Broeke
citation.unstructured_citation: • Broeke M, Box J, Fettweis X, Hanna E, Noël B, Tedesco M, et al. Greenland ice sheet surface mass loss: recent developments in observation and modeling. Curr Clim Change Rep. 2017;2:345–56. Presents the current state of knowledge for modeling the surface mass balance of the Greenland ice sheet.
